title: Dax Compact vs. Condensed
content:
Hi there.

I noticed there's a Dax Compact, and a Dax Condensed.  
I know what condensed is, but what does Compact mean?  
What's the difference?

Thx.
author: LasseFernov

comments.content:
Compact is more condensed, I think.

-- [astype.de](http://web.archive.org/web/20131020041651/http:/www.astype.de/)--

Actually, [FF Dax Condensed](http://web.archive.org/web/20131020041651/http:/www.fontshop.com/showfont.cfm?fid=FF.10001.0.0) is about the same width as [FF Dax Compact](http://web.archive.org/web/20131020041651/http:/www.fontshop.com/showfont.cfm?fid=FF.11416.0.0). The main difference is the latter has...

"relatively small ascenders and descenders and the uppercase letters have the same height as the lowercase ascenders. This makes the typeface optically larger -- useful for headlines and posters where words must shout." - Hans Reichel

Typically the terms compact and compressed refer to a width narrower than condensed. This width is almost always used only for large display sizes. Condensed can be used (in small doses) for text.  
From what Stephen says, I infer that FF is using the compact description to indicate that it is a headline font.

ChrisL

Ahh ok - That makes sense.  
Thank you.
